newsitem.title: IRAN: Iran checks area jolted by second quake in two days.
newsitem.headline: Iran checks area jolted by second quake in two days.

text.p: The death toll from an earthquake which rocked Iran's northwestern Ardabil region rose on Monday to 600 as rescue teams searched a mountainous region to assess damage from the second earthquake that hit the area in two days.
An Iranian Red Crescent official told Reuters no reports had been received yet but some casualties were expected in the latest quake measuring 5.2 on the Richter scale.
It struck on Sunday night, two days after a stronger quake measuring 5.5 on the Richter scale left 35,000 people homeless in heavy snow and sub-freezing conditions.
Seifollah Vahid Dastjerdi, the head of the Red Crescent, said the death toll of Friday's quake, had risen to 600 and that more than 2,500 were injured.
State-run Tehran radio earlier said Sunday's tremor and its aftershocks destroyed some buildings in areas already damaged on Friday, prompting residents to flee their homes in fear.
"Power has been cut in most towns and villages," it said.
There have been about 350 aftershocks since Friday's quake in Ardabil province on Iran's border with Azerbaijan, the official news agency IRNA said.
Iranian media said units of the army and the Revolutionary Guards had joined about 5,000 relief workers already involved in rescue operations.
Dastjerdi, quoted by IRNA, expressed satisfaction with the pace of relief operations.
He said that so far more than 8,700 tents, 21,800 blankets, 15,300 heaters and lanterns, 2,000 cans of baby formula and 80 tonnes of bread had been distributed to the victims.
Some 60 ambulances, 127 trucks and vans and two helicopters were transferring the injured, relief workers and supplies to and from the stricken region, he said.
Dastjerdi added that Switzerland, Britain, Japan and some international relief organisations had offered to send aid.
Michael Schulenburg, U.N. resident coordinator in Tehran, told Reuters the United Nations was trying to mobilise international assistance which Iran had said it would welcome.
"We have a U.N. team visiting the area today to draw up a complete list of what kind of aid is needed. There is urgent need for food. Also for blankets, water and heaters.
"Conditions are bad and as until last night it was still snowing and access to villages is proving difficult.

"It is very difficult to get a final casualty figure and there are delays because the villages are far away and the weather is not helping. I expect the number to go up but not to the thousands because the area is not a main urban one," Schulenberg said.

Television footage showed scores of people, most of them crying, gathered around an ambulance carrying 10 bodies, including those of six children. Graves were being dug and a Moslem cleric was on hand to pray for the dead.
Ardabil is an agricultural province inhabited mainly by Iran's Azeri minority. It is one of Iran's coldest regions with freezing temperatures during the winter.
In early February, two earthquakes measuring 6.1 and 5.4 on the Richter scale killed at least 79 people and injured 260 in northeastern Iran.
Earthquakes hit Iran regularly. The worst recorded one, measuring 7.3 on the Richter scale, killed 35,000 people in an area near the Caspian coast in 1990.
